reasoning: The critique targets Counterargument 7 (“strongest link” framing). That point is only one of several independent reasons the position gives for discounting compute bottlenecks, so even fully refuting it wouldn’t seriously undermine the overall conclusion (moderate-low centrality). Within that sub-argument, the critique is fairly forceful: for an ongoing intelligence-explosion feedback loop, it’s not enough that some pathway is temporarily less compute-bottlenecked; it needs to remain so across many iterations, and the original text doesn’t really justify that durability (moderate strength). The critique’s main claims are broadly right, though it overstates “inconsistency” a bit since the position could respond that the system can continually shift to the currently-best route rather than rely on a single fixed one (high but not perfect correctness). It is concise and understandable (high clarity) with minimal filler (low dead weight) and stays focused on one issue (single-issue = 1). Overall it’s a useful local objection but not a major threat to the full position.
title: The strongest link framing cannot justify sustained acceleration across iterations
